label: SAMPLE: Interview with Beulah  Collins, August 1, 1983

source.title: Hometown of Snow Hill, Maryland: Life on the farm
source.description: Beulah Collins speaks fondly about growing up in the country, raising chickens and growing vegetables.

source.title: Moving to Philadelphia, circa 1919
source.partial_transcript: When did you come up to Philadelphia? When did you come north?
source.description: Collins discusses her decision to move north after her husband died during the 1918 influenza epidemic and her parents passed away, taking her siblings' advice to seek opportunities for better wages and an education for her son.

source.title: Domestic service: Living with the Richard family in Philadelphia
source.partial_transcript: So when you came up here, then, did you go to work?
source.description: Collins explains how she began working as a domestic worker for the wealthy Richard family on Chestnut Hill.

source.title: On boarding her son with "Mom" Taylor
source.partial_transcript: But ahead of my story before then. I did work for another lady out, way out in Ardmore somewhere.
source.description: Collins recounts spending a portion of her earnings paying â€œMom" Taylor to look after her only son, as he could not live with her at the Richard residence. She shares her happiness and contentment that "Mom" Taylor treated her son like one of her own children.

source.title: Domestic service in Philadelphia
source.partial_transcript: Now, um, you know, I'm very interested in finding out more about domestic service.
source.description: Collins describes how she was "pretty well satisfied" doing domestic work to ensure her son had a good education. She shares how she used to go up and look at the brides during weddings at a church on Saint Martins Lane.

source.title: Domestic service: Low wages
source.description: Collins shares how she made $13 a week and how she had to stretch it to provide for her son. She talks about how she always had enough to eat during the Great Depression because she lived with the Richards family. She also shares her feelings about wearing a uniform, which the family bought for her.

source.title: Domestic service: Long hours
source.description: Collins recounts her daily routine and duties as a domestic worker, including squeezing fresh orange juice for breakfast, sweeping the porch, making the beds, getting the boys off to school, serving the meals, washing the dishes, and tidying the house. Once a week, she polished the silver. Mrs. Richard hired another woman to do the heavy washing and ironing. She shares that her days began at 7:00am and ended at 8:00pm, thirteen hours hours later. She says that she had Sundays and Thursday afternoons off. Still, she rarely complained. She also shares that one of the Richard's sons married a granddaughter of Washington Atlee Burpee, the founder of Burpee Seed Company.

source.title: Work options as a Black woman in Philadelphia
source.partial_transcript: Now when you came up you were a young woman up from the South--
source.description: Collins describes learning to be a good live-in domestic, and discusses her distaste for laundry and factory work.

source.title: Memories of the South and her husband's death in 1918
source.partial_transcript: How, how do you think, uh--how did Philadelphia compare to, uh, to--when you, when you arrived in the city, when you were first living here, I guess after you moved in from Ardmore.
source.description: Collins reminisces about life on the farm as a young woman and shares the reasons why she never had a desire to return to Maryland. She explains why she never remarried for fear that a new husband might not be good to her son. She shares how she heard about her husband's death at Fort Meade in 1918 and how she intends to be buried beside him when she dies.

source.title: Memories of her childhood as a tenant farmer's daughter
source.partial_transcript: Now, did your family, uh--you grew up on the farm, right?
source.description: Collins recalls the crops her father grew as a tenant farmer: wheat, corn, potatoes, and "most everything," She speculates about the course her life may have taken had she stayed in the South.
